lines.text:
[after a dinner where Terry Randall has evidently spoken very eloquently about Shakespeare]
Well, I don't like to gossip, but that new gal seems to have an awful crush on Shakespeare!

[jokingly]
I wouldn't be surprised if they get married!

[with genuine naiveté]
Oh, you're foolin'! Shakespeare's dead!

[Feigning surprise, playing along to entertain the others]
No!
Well, if he's the same one that wrote "Hamlet", he is!

[playing along, too]
Never heard of it.
Well, certainly you must have heard of "Hamlet"!
Well, I meet so many people.

[delivering her opening speech in the play within the movie]
The calla lilies are in bloom again. Such a strange flower, suitable to any occasion. I carried them on my wedding day and now I place them here in memory of something that has died.

[giving her curtain speech at the end of a trimphant opening night performance of the play within the movie]
The person you should be applauding died a few hours ago. I hope that wherever she is, she knows and understands and forgives.
I see that, in addition to your other charms, you have that insolence generated by an inferior upbringing.
Hmm! Fancy clothes, fancy language and everything!
Unfortunately, I learned to speak English correctly.
That won't be of much use to you here. We all talk pig latin.
We started off on the wrong foot. Let's stay that way.
When I get back to my room, you're the only thing I want to find missing.

[entering the boarding house after trying the wrong door]
How many doors are there to this place?
Well, there's the trap door, the humidor, and the cuspidor. How many doors would you like?
Do you mind if I ask a personal question?
Another one?
Are these trunks full of bodies?
Just those, but I don't intend to unpack them.
Hey, that's a kind of good-lookin' piece of jackrabbit you got there.
Oh, it's just a little trinket my "Aunt Susan" sent over.
Say, I think it's very unselfish of those little animals to give up their lives to keep other animals warm.
You know, they're very smart little animals. They never give up their lives for the wrong people.
Well, you understand the rodent family much better than I do.

[crassly screaming from the bottom of the stairs]
OH, LINDA!

[coming down the stairs]
Maybe if you spoke a little LOUDER next time, everyone in the whole HOUSE could hear you.

[sarcastically]
Oh, I'm sorry, I forget that you're old and deaf.
Hey, you're not gonna catch the opening tonight, huh?
No, I'm going tomorrow and catch the closing.
Do you want a date?
To some other lumberman?
Am I supposed to apologize for being born in Seattle?
Well, the last couple we went stepping with were made of lumber. Especially their feet.
All right, all right, you can stay here and gorge yourself on lamb stew again.

If you were a little more considerate of your elders, maybe Mr. Powell would send his car for you someday. Of course, he would probably take one look at you and send you right back again, but then you have to expect that.
Is that so?
Do you know, I think I could fix you up with Mr. Powell's chauffeur. The chauffeur has a very nice car too.
Yes, but I understand Mr. Powell's chauffeur doesn't go as far in his car as Mr. Powell does.
Even a chauffer has to have an incentive!
Well, you should know!

[With a superior air, leaving the crowded living room of girls after many snappy wisecracks and lively banter among the group]
It'd be a terrific innovation if you could get your minds stretched a little further than the next wisecrack.
A pleasant little foursome. I predict a hatchet murder before the night's over.
One of the best press campaigns...
[Offers Jean cigaret]
No thanks. Gave it up when I was seven.
Bright girl. Busy tonight?
Yes.
[Following routine lines omitted]
Well, you haven't given up eating, have you?
It isn't that. It's - just that I think we hadn't better see each other for a while.
Why?
I just think it's better, that's all.

[long pause]
O-h-h-h.
Why do you say "o-h-h-h" like that?
Well, how would you say it?
You make it sound like it meant something else.
Well, does it?
Whatever I do is my own business.
Are you coming or aren't you?
Oh shut up.
Did you eat something sour for lunch today?

[to Linda Shaw as she is leaving for a dinner date]
Don't chew the bones and give yourself away!
Hey Kay! why didn't you ay hello to me?
I'm sorry, I didn't see you.
Well, you couldn't help but hear me.
Maybe I could fix you up with Mr. Powell's chauffeur. the chauffeur has a very nice car too.
Yes, but I'm told the chauffeur doesn't go as far in his car aa Mr. Powell does.
I hate that word "stooge," I'm retained as an *escort*.

[to Terry]
You're an actress now. You belong to these people.
